Award.AwardTitle: Large-Scale Investigations of Quasar Wind Variability with the Sloan Digital Sky Survey
Award.AbstractNarration:
A longstanding problem in astrophysics is to understand how galaxies form and develop throughout their lifetimes. Such understanding is necessary to uncover how our Universe evolved and to gain insight into the origin of our own Milky Way Galaxy. One important aspect of understanding galaxy formation and evolution is to study supermassive black holes (SMBHs) at the centers of galaxies and how these SMBHs are linked to their host galaxies. Quasar winds are fundamentally linked to mass accretion onto rapidly growing SMBHs, and they also likely serve as agents of SMBH feedback into typical massive galaxies. This project will advance understanding of several key aspects of quasar winds using an unprecedentedly large---and still growing---spectroscopic survey of multi-year ultraviolet broad absorption line (BAL) variability in about 2100 BAL quasars. This survey is primarily based on spectra from the ongoing Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS) and is about two orders of magnitude larger than past comparable surveys; supporting targeted spectroscopy is also obtained via Penn State's access to the queue-scheduled Hobby-Eberly Telescope.

The PI's annual summer workshops will serve as a high-leverage way of helping about 50 Pennsylvania high school teachers educate their thousands of students better about space, time, gravity, black holes, and the scientific method. Teachers from underserved rural and urban school districts, including underrepresented minorities and women, will be specifically recruited with scholarship funds. The workshops' programs will include an overview of the project's scientific discoveries and an associated activity, and the postdoctoral research associate will help with workshop planning and presentation. The postdoctoral researcher will also work as a central member of PI's group, thereby developing his or her research, teaching, and outreach skills. He or she will lead much of the analysis as well as many of the high-impact journal articles and presentations. The postdoctoral researcher will also be a primary mentor of the undergraduate researcher, who will develop hands-on research skills via well-defined projects.

More technically, this project will use its database to provide the following specific advances: (1) unmatched large-scale measurements/limits of BAL acceleration and deceleration that constrain BAL-wind feedback into galaxies; (2) measurements of BAL vs. emission-line properties that test the drivers of BAL variability and quasar-wind models; (3) determination of the in-depth relations between BAL disappearance and emergence with associated improvements in direct BAL-lifetime estimates; (4) an understanding of the nature of unusually stable BALs and their possible relation to ongoing large-scale galactic feedback; and (5) determination of whether remarkable redshifted BAL troughs arise from rotationally dominated outflows or high-velocity infalling material. These results will play an important role in transforming the field of multi-year BAL variability studies into one that supplies rigorous, large-sample constraints that can effectively guide models of quasar winds and their feedback. They are expected to be the best such results available for at least a decade.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main research activity has been a large-scale survey of quasar wind variability, specifically those winds observed via rest-frame ultraviolet absorption lines in Broad Absorption Line (BAL) quasars. 

The Time Domain Spectroscopic Survey (TDSS), part of the  Sloan Digital Sky Survey-IV (SDSS-IV), is a six-year program (2014-2020) that has used the 2.5-m SDSS telescope to explore systematically the optically variable universe from a spectroscopic perspective. The resulting spectra, covering 3600-10000 Angstroms, are well suited to quasar-physics studies. A key component of TDSS, and the subject of this report, is focused on studying BAL variability on multi-year timescales in the rest frame. The main goal of this project has been to move from small-sample and single-object studies of multi-year BAL variability to setting large-sample statistical constraints that can be compared with models of quasar winds. The basic approach was to re-target about 2100 optically bright BAL quasars already observed from 2000-2014 by SDSS-I/II/III. This uniformly defined sample is about 100 times larger than past samples that had been used to study BAL variability on multi-year timescales in the rest frame. 

With significant effort, we have analyzed the resulting spectra of our BAL quasars to study the nature of multi-year BAL variability. We have used our measurements to investigate topics including BAL disappearance/emergence; BAL acceleration; very high velocity BALs; the nature of BALs with redshifted troughs; rapid BAL variability; and the general variability behavior of low-ionization BALs. Several postdoctoral researchers and graduate students, as well as an undergraduate, were developed via the activities of this grant; they have now gone on to successful positions in academia and the private sector. 

Multiple primary papers from this project have now been published and publicly released, and a few of them are highlighted here. The first presented results from the largest systematic investigation of BAL acceleration to date, finding a few cases of apparent BAL acceleration and also setting tight constraints upon acceleration for many other BAL troughs. The second presented the discovery of the highest velocity (~ 60,000 km/s) C IV BAL to date in a z = 2.47 quasar; this result was featured in a press release. The third investigated BAL disappearance using multi-epoch spectra of more than 1500 quasars, the largest sample ever used for such a study, and estimated the average lifetime of a BAL along our line of sight (80-100 yr). The fourth systematically investigated short-timescale (< 10 rest-frame days) C IV BAL variability to constrain quasar-wind properties and provide insights into BAL-variability mechanisms in quasars, employing rapid cadence data taken by the SDSS Reverberation Mapping Project. The fifth performed the first large-sample statistical characterization of Mg II BAL variability, using 134 bona fide Mg II BAL quasars covering days to ~ 10 yr in the rest frame. Furthermore, this NSF support has allowed collaboration on highly relevant additional projects.

The main educational/outreach activity associated with this project, aside from the student and postdoctoral mentoring, involved the Penn State Science Workshops for Educators. Each summer Brandt is the lead instructor for one intensive week-long workshop with about 10-20 high-school (and sometimes middle-school) teachers; his recent workshops have been titled "Black Holes: Gravity's Fatal Attraction" and "The Origins and Fate of our Cosmos: Understanding Big Bang Cosmology". The programs for these workshops include lectures on the subject material; discussions about pedagogical approaches; hands-on activities; examinations of curricular materials; nighttime observing; and guest presentations by professional astronomers, graduate students, and science education specialists. For example, Brandt's cosmology workshop shows teachers what modern observational and theoretical work has taught us about the origin, fate, and nature of the Universe. The pillars and successes of the Big Bang model are examined in detail. Topics covered include the size and age of the Universe; the darkness of the night sky and its implications; the expansion of the Universe and the Big Bang; the large-scale structure of the Universe; the cosmic evolution of galaxies and quasars; the Cosmic Microwave Background; creating the light elements in the Big Bang; dark matter on all scales; dark energy and the accelerating Universe; the ultimate fate of the Universe; the first stars, galaxies, and black holes; the very early Universe and inflation; the possibility of a Multiverse; the future of cosmology; and techniques for teaching cosmology in the classroom. These workshops have been highly successful as judged by the reviews and direct teacher feedback. As parts of these workshops, Brandt presented an overview of the science results from this project. These workshops are a high-leverage method of improving high-school and middle-school astronomy education throughout Pennsylvania and its neighboring states; each of the participating teachers will teach hundreds of students in the coming years.
